slide.title: Which disabilities benefit from Bypass Blocks?

p.a: W3C WAI Stories on how people use the web.

ul.li: Keyboard only or mostly users who cannot or have difficulty using pointing and touch devices.
Assistive technologies that emulate the keyboard (e.g. on-screen keyboards, voice recognition) are used to navigate and interact with web pages.
Screen reader users were the primary advocates of the original bypass blocks requirement.

Improvements in web design and screen reader support for heading and landmark navigation have made the "Skip to Main Content" link less important to screen reader users.
NOTE: For example h1 elements and/or main landmarks are typically used for the main content and screen readers have built-in commands to navigate to these locations.

slide.title: Goals of SkipTo script and browser extensions

ul.li: Improve keyboard accessibility to web page content. Basically give all users some of the header and landmark navigation features available in screen readers.
Allow authors to identify more than one important navigational point within web resources.
Simplify implementation of WCAG 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks of Content requirement.
Make header and landmark region information available to everyone to promote a better understanding of accessibility.

tr.td: Physical Impairment

ul.li: Improved options for keyboard navigation to regions of a web page.

If SkipTo button visible when page loads:
Feature easy to identify without interacting with the page.
Voice recognition users can just say "click skip to content" to get a list of regions.

tr.td: Blind and Low Vision

ul.li: Get a filtered list of landmarks and headings to find author identified important regions of a web page.

tr.td: Everyone

ul.li: View high level outline of the regions of a web page.
Directly navigate to a regions using the mouse.
People not familiar with landmarks and/or headings can learn about them in a functional way.

tr.td: Designers and Developers

ul.li: Use existing landmarks and headings to identify important regions of a web page.
Provide high level outline of the regions of a web page to all users.
Support easy verification of the functional use landmarks and headings for oriention and navigation to page content.
Button visible by default.
Button placement and styling.

slide.title: SkipTo Landmarks & Headings Browser Extensions for Chrome and Firefox

ul.li: Adds the SkipTo functionality to the Chrome and Firefox browsers.
Provides access to the landmark and heading strucuture of web pages for anyone to benefit.

Implements a W3C User Agent Accessibility Guidelines requirement for:
1.9.1 Outline View
2.2.2 Sequential Navigation Between Landmarks:

img.alt: Screen shot of open menu of the SkipTo Landmarks and Headings extension on the IBM price, the menu and toolbar button are highlighted

ul.li: Use existing page landmark and heading structure to generate a menu for orientation and navigation.
SkipTo is a major advancement in implementing the WCAG 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks of Content requirement for web pages.
SkipTo Landmarks & Headings browser extensions for Chrome and Firefox implements a long standing browser accessbility requirement for keyboard navigation to structural content.
